docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: The HUD is the primary flight reference in visual, close-range air combat. It enables radar acquisition and weapons employment without looking inside the cockpit, enhancing situational awareness and reducing pilot workload. However, it's essential to maintain a disciplined cross-check and avoid fixating solely on the HUD, as this can lead to neglecting other critical flight information (e.g., terrain, target aircraft).

docs.title: HUD Limitations in NAV/INST Master Modes
docs.text:
• Limited A/A Data: Only the TD (Target Designator) box is displayed.
  • Radar Display: The primary source of target/missile information.
  • Recommendation: Avoid using NAV or INST master modes for A/A engagements.

docs.title: A/G Master Mode
docs.text: No A/A information is displayed on the HUD, although it's available on the A/A radar display.

docs.title: A/A Master Mode Selection
docs.text:
• Methods:

    • Press the A/A master mode button.
    • Move the FCP (Front Cockpit) castle switch forward (if not already in A/A).
    • Select GUN on the weapon select switch.

  • Toggling: Subsequent forward movements of the FCP castle switch will toggle between A/A and A/G master modes.

docs.title: Weapon Select Switch Control
docs.text: Once in A/A master mode, the HUD attack displays are determined by the weapon select switch position (AFT/CTR/FWD).

docs.title: Radar Modes and HUD Display
docs.text:
Certain radar modes, like SNF (Sniff) and VI (Visual Identification), influence the information presented on the HUD.

  • SNF Cue: Displayed on the HUD when the radar is operating in SNF mode (Figure D-1).

[Figure D-1: SNIFF]

  • VI Mode:
    • TD Box: Appears when the radar is in single target track (STT) or designated track-while-scan (DTWS) and VI is selected (Figure D-2).
    • No Steering Cues: ASE (Allowable Steering Error) circle and steering dot are removed.
    • 12° MRM (Medium Range Missile) Reference Circle: Provides a visual cue for AIM-7/AIM-120 employment without radar lock-on.

[Figure D-2: Visual Identification Selected]

docs.title: Limited TD Box
docs.text:
• Dashed Target Locator Line: Extends from the waterline symbol and points towards the TD box when it's limited by the HUD field of view.
  • Off-Boresight Angle: Displayed next to the TD box, representing the target's angular offset from boresight in degrees (Figure D-3).

Note: The absence of heading, bank scales, and the pitch ladder in the figures indicates that "symbols reject" is active.

[Figure D-3: HUD Limited TD Box, VI Selected]

docs.title: Degrees Before Break Lock
docs.text:
• Expanded Azimuth Display Mode: When this radar mode is active and the off-boresight angle reaches 65°, the degrees remaining before radar break-lock are displayed above or below the waterline (Figure D-4).

[Figure D-4: Degrees Before Break Lock, VI Selected]

docs.title: Range Bar
docs.text:
• Appearance: When the target is within 12,000 feet (Figure D-5).
  • Range Indication: The clock position of the end tab shows target range (6 o'clock = 6,000 feet).

[Figure D-5: Radar Track, VI Target at 0.5 nm]

docs.title: ASE Circle Expansion
docs.text:
• Close Range: As the aircraft closes on the target, the ASE circle expands.
  • Steering Dot Placement: Placing the steering dot on the circle will guide the aircraft to a 500-foot separation from the target (Figure D-5).

docs.title: Scan Pattern Display
docs.text: The selected radar auto acquisition mode (except for GUNS) is displayed graphically on the HUD. This helps the pilot keep the target within the scan until radar lock-on is achieved.

docs.title: Track Display
docs.text: After radar lock-on (regardless of the method), the track display on the HUD (and radar) is determined by the weapon select switch position (FCP right throttle).

docs.title: Representative Displays
docs.text: • Figures D-6 and D-7 depict typical AIM-7 attack mode displays with symbols reject active and the master arm switch in ARM (gun cross displayed 2° above the waterline).

docs.title: Radar Lock-On
docs.text:
• Removed: 12° MRM reference circle.
  • Displayed: ASE circle, steering dot, TD box.

docs.title: Figure D-6: Inside Rpi (Priority Intercept Range)
docs.text:
[Figure D-6: Radar Track, Inside Rpi]

  • Information Displayed:
    • Range Scale: Selected radar range (uppermost number), Vc (closure velocity) to the left of the caret, PDT (Primary Designated Target) range indicated by the caret position, priority missile launch range boundaries.
    • Data Block (Lower Right):
      • PDT altitude (thousands and hundreds of feet)
      • Aspect angle (degrees L/R)
      • Radar cues (e.g., JAM for jamming present)
      • PDT radar range (digital)
      • Priority missile TOF (time of flight) when PDT range is between Raero (current) and Rmin.
      • In-flight missile time information (minimum/maximum time to impact [TTD] if multiple missiles are airborne).
      • PACS training status (TRNG if A/A Training is "boxed").

docs.title: Shoot Cue
docs.text:
• Display: Triangular AIM-7 shoot cue appears below the TD box (above if the box is in the lower HUD half) when preconditions are met. Lock/shoot lights also illuminate.
  • Flashing: When target range is between Rtr (tracking range) and Rmin.

docs.title: Figure D-7: Inside Rmin (Minimum Range)
docs.text:
[Figure D-7: Radar Track, Inside Rmin, Flashing Off Missile Cue]

  • Displayed: Break X symbol.
  • Removed: ASE circle, steering dot, shoot cue.
  • Break X Status:
    • Steady: Missile in flight.
    • Flashing: All other times.
  • Off Missile Cue: If another weapon is within launch parameters, its cue flashes next to the priority MRM inventory (in this case, an AIM-9M with three missiles available).

docs.title: Radar Signal Loss
docs.text:
• Track Memory and Reacquisition: Activated upon signal loss.
  • Displayed: MEM cue on the HUD and flashing TD box (MEM also appears on the radar display).
  • Radar Function: Extrapolates last known target position and velocity.
  • Jamming: If signal loss is due to ECM, the jam code (AOJ, HOJ, JAM) takes precedence over other data block displays.
  • Signal Recovery: Radar resumes normal track.
  • Signal Loss (No Recovery): Radar returns to search.
  • Post-Launch Signal Loss: LSG (Losing) replaces missile TOF.

docs.title: Launch Modes
docs.text:
• Visual: For visual range engagements.
  • Radar: Guided by radar track.

docs.title: Visual Mode
docs.text:
• Scenario: For example, while an AIM-7 is in flight with another ready to launch, the pilot can cycle to an AIM-120 using the missile reject (boat switch).
  • Coolie Switch: Holding it down designates a boresighted target (within the 12° reference circle) with unknown range/velocity (no data link provided).
  • Caution: Exercise care, as any aircraft within the missile's boresight is a potential target.

docs.title: Figure D-8: AIM-120A Display
docs.text:
[Figure D-8: Radar Track, AIM-120A Display]

  • Information Displayed:
    • MRM Inventory: Shows four AIM-120s available with an AIM-120A prioritized.
    • Missile Type: A2A is displayed for AIM-120A priority, M2M for AIM-7M priority.
    • ASE Circle: Dashed line (mirrors radar display).
    • Shoot Cue: Similar logic to AIM-7, generated by the CC when the radar is in STT or DTWS (assuming all other preconditions are met).
    • Target Size/RCS: Displayed next to the MRM inventory (overridden by the off-missile cue if another weapon is within parameters). Consult 1F-15E-34-1-1 and 1F-15E-34-1-1-1 for more information on these settings.

docs.title: Data Block
docs.text:
• Similar to AIM-7: Provides AIM-120-specific information.
  • TTA (Time to Active): Displayed instead of TOF when target range is between Raero and Rmin.
  • TTI (Time to Impact): Displayed when the range is less than active range.
    • "H" Prefix: Missile will go HPRF active immediately after launch.
    • "M" Prefix: Missile will go MPRF active.

docs.title: Post-Launch
docs.text:
• MRM Count: Decrements.
  • TTA: Begins countdown on the next lower line.
  • Multiple Launches: TTA cue reflects the minimum/maximum TTA/TTI of all airborne missiles.
  • Off-Missile Cue: Same logic as for AIM-7.

docs.title: Last MRM Launched (Figure D-9)
docs.text:
[Figure D-9: Radar Track, MRM Selected]

  • MRM Count: Zero.
  • Removed: ASE circle.
  • Displayed: Steering dot (based on MRM calculations).
  • Removed: Shoot cue.

docs.title: AIM-9M
docs.text: Note: AIM-9 Special Burst Ranging and Combined Modes are covered in AAW-5 (AIM-9M) and AAW-6 (GUN), respectively.

docs.title: Visual (Radar in Search)
docs.text:
• Seeker Head Position Circle: Centered within the FOV (Field of View) circle on the HUD (Figure D-10).
  • FOV Circle Size: Dependent on the SCAN option setting in the PACS.

[Figure D-10: Radar Search, Scan Not Selected]

docs.title: Uncage (Self Track)
docs.text:
• Target in FOV: Pilot can select uncage by pressing and releasing the NGS (Nose Gear Steering) button (Figure D-11).
  • Seeker Lock-On Indication:
    • Removal of FOV circle.
    • Detection tone changes to a self-track tone.
  • Seeker Head Position Circle: Tracks the target when in self-track.

[Figure D-11: Radar Search, Uncage Selected, Missile Self Track]

docs.title: Display (Figure D-12)
docs.text:
[Figure D-12: Seeker Slaved to Radar LOS (Not Uncaged)]

  • ASE Circle and Steering Dot: Replace the FOV circle (ASE size is constant regardless of SCAN setting).
  • Aspect Line (Stick): Present on the ASE circle when the range is greater than 12,000 feet.
  • Range Bar:
    • Appears inside the ASE circle when the target is 12,000 feet or closer.
    • Range is read by clock position (7 o'clock = 7,000 feet).
  • Rmin LC/HC Bars: Reflect the minimum range for the missile (repeats the radar range scale display).
  • Seeker Head Position Circle: Coincident with the TD box (slaved to radar LOS). May be temporarily offset during high-G maneuvers.

docs.title: Uncaging Before Launch
docs.text:
• Recommendation: Uncage the AIM-9M to ensure missile self-track.
  • Indication: ASE circle doubles in size (still represents the steering envelope), and the tone increases in pitch.
  • Offset Seeker Circle: May occur due to missile and aircraft tolerances (Figure D-13).

[Figure D-13: Seeker Uncaged and Locked On, Shoot Cue]

docs.title: Shoot Cue Conditions
docs.text:
Flashing shoot cue and lock/shoot lights are displayed when:

  • Radar is in STT or DTWS.
  • Target range is between Rmax LC (maximum range, low confidence) and Rmin LC.
  • Steering dot is inside the ASE circle.
  • Seeker/radar LOS coincidence is within 2°.

docs.title: Manual Boresight
docs.text:
• Purpose: Enables engaging a visual target while the radar is guiding an AIM-7/AIM-120.
  • Display:
    • ASE circle and steering dot are removed.
    • FOV circle replaces ASE.
    • Shoot cue is not displayed (Figure D-14).

[Figure D-14: Radar Track, Manual Boresight]

docs.title: Manual Boresight Procedure (From Self-Track)
docs.text:
1. Cage the seeker to the radar LOS (NGS button).

  2. Move the coolie switch down and hold to boresight the missile.

  3. Coolie Switch Release (Before Uncage): Seeker returns to radar LOS (TD box).

  4. Flashing FOV Circle: Indicates the radar antenna is approaching gimbal limits.

docs.title: No SRM Available (Figure D-15)
docs.text:
[Figure D-15: SRM, No Missile Available]

  • SRM Count: Zero.
  • Removed: ASE circle and steering dot.
  • Shoot Cue: Not displayed.
  • Analog Range Bar: Continues providing range and minimum range cues for the PDT.

docs.title: Possible HUD Displays
docs.text:
• LCOS (Lead Computing Optical Sight) Search Funnel
  • LCOS Track Funnel
  • GDS (Gun Director Sight)
  • GDS Funnel

Display Selection: Based on radar track and funnel selection status.

Note: Air-to-air gun employment and combined SRM/GUN displays are covered in AAW-6.

docs.title: Unique GUN Symbols
docs.text:
• Funnel
  • Reticles
  • RATR (Rounds at Target Range) cue
  • BMR (Bullet Maximum Range) cue
  • Rounds remaining numerics

Gun Cross: Displayed when the master arm switch is in ARM.

docs.title: LCOS Search Funnel (Figure D-16)
docs.text:
[Figure D-16: LCOS Search Funnel]

  • Conditions: GUN selected on the weapon select switch, radar in search mode.
  • Function: Aids in aligning with the target to achieve a stable tracking state.
  • Pippers: Three 2-mil circles located at pseudo target ranges of 1,000, 2,250, and 4,000 feet (with PGU-28 loaded in the PACS).
  • Funnel Width: Based on the apparent size of a 40-foot wingspan aircraft at the corresponding range (stadiametric ranging).
  • Tracking Solution: Place one of the pippers on the target, visually confirm the range matches the pipper's designated range, and fire.

docs.title: RATR Cue
docs.text:
• Purpose: Shows where bullets will impact at a pseudo target range of 2,250 feet (1,000 feet in STIFFEN mode).
  • Duration: Present from the first bullet's arrival until the last bullet in the burst.

docs.title: Rounds Remaining Display
docs.text:
• Indication: Approximate number of rounds loaded in the PACS and not yet fired.
  • Decrement: Decreases by 10 during firing.
  • Training Mode: "T" appended to the last digit (e.g., 51T).
  • Expended Rounds: "XXX" displayed (or "XXT" in training mode).

docs.title: LCOS Track Funnel (Figure D-17)
docs.text:
[Figure D-17: LCOS Track Funnel]

  • Conditions: GUN selected, radar in single target track.
  • Additional Symbology/Data: Compared to the LCOS search funnel, this display incorporates radar track information.

docs.title: Reticle and Funnel Movement
docs.text:
• Reticle: 2-mil pipper and 25-mil segmented circle.
  • Positioning: Based on:
    • Radar target range/range rate
    • Ownship maneuvering parameters

docs.title: Range Bar
docs.text:
• Purpose: Shows radar-derived range in an analog "clock" format.
  • Movement: Starts at 12 o'clock and moves clockwise.
  • Range Reading: Leading edge indicates range in thousands of feet (e.g., 3 o'clock = 3,000 feet).

docs.title: GDS (Figure D-18)
docs.text:
[Figure D-18: GDS]

  • Conditions: GUN selected, full radar lock-on achieved.
  • "GDS" Display: Appears in the lower right HUD (window 17).

docs.title: Reticle, Range Bar, and BMR
docs.text:
• Reticle: 2-mil pipper, 50-mil reticle, turn plane line.

  • Positioning: Based on:

    • Ownship maneuvering
    • Target range/range rate/maneuvering

  • Range Bar: Functions as described previously, but with a leading edge tab.

  • BMR (Bullet Maximum Range) Cue:

    • Dot positioned on the 50-mil reticle perimeter.
    • Indicates maximum effective bullet range based on:
      • Round type (loaded in PACS).
      • Ownship/target maneuvering and relative position.
    • Range reading: Same as range bar (e.g., BMR dot at 3 o'clock = 3,000 feet).
    • Represents:
      • The range corresponding to a 1.5-second bullet TOF (M-56) or 2.5-second bullet TOF (PGU-28).
      • Impact velocity of 500 FPS, whichever results in the shorter range.

  • Maximum Accurate Firing Range: Achieved when the range bar tab aligns with the BMR cue.

docs.title: TD Box Removal/Reappearance
docs.text:
• Removed: When its center is within 25 mils of the pipper and the target range is less than 3,000 feet (or the maximum bullet range, whichever is greater).
  • Reappears: When the range increases to 3,200 feet (or 200 feet greater than the maximum bullet range) or when the box center is more than 37 mils from the pipper.

docs.title: GDS Funnel (Figure D-19)
docs.text:
[Figure D-19: GDS Funnel]

  • Conditions: GUN mode entered, radar has single target track.
  • Toggling: Activate the coolie switch upward to switch between GDS and GDS Funnel.
  • "FNL" Display: Appears in HUD window 17 when GDS Funnel is active.
  • Display Combination: Merges the GDS reticle and LCOS track funnel displays (turn plane line is replaced by the funnel).
  • Dual Solutions: The GDS reticle and LCOS track funnel provide two aiming solutions.

docs.title: CC Failure
docs.text:
• Loss of Steering Data: All MRM and SRM computer-generated attack steering data is lost.
  • No Shoot Cue: Launch envelopes must be estimated.
  • Displayed: Fixed 12° MRM reference circle (provides visual aiming reference for no-lock launches).
  • Radar: STT (Single Target Track) is available.
  • AIM-7 Launch (STT): Provides 120 seconds of HPRF illumination.
  • AIM-120: Cannot be fired.

  • AIM-9M:

    • Seeker head reference circle not displayed.
    • Missiles boresighted to 0° azimuth and 46 mils below the gun cross.
    • Seekers will not slave to radar.
    • Waterline can be used as an aiming reference.
    • No HUD cues for uncaged and track status.

  • Gun:

    • Cross is continuously displayed.
    • Becomes the only gun aiming reference.

docs.title: PACS Failure
docs.text: • Data Loss: CC loses PACS inputs, resulting in the absence of most ordnance-related HUD data (ASE circle, steering dot, launch range boundaries, missile/bullet inventories, etc.).

docs.title: INS Failure
docs.text:
• AHRS Backup: The Attitude Heading Reference System (AHRS) automatically provides backup attitude data, so INS failure shouldn't significantly degrade HUD weapons displays (other than a flashing velocity vector).
  • Dual Failure (INS and AHRS): Results in loss of heading, bank scales, and the pitch ladder, potentially mimicking the "symbols reject" mode. Be aware of other indications of complete attitude failure.

docs.title: MPDP Failure
docs.text: Loss of the entire HUD display.

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text:
• A/A: Air-to-air
  • A/G: Air-to-ground
  • AHRS: Attitude Heading Reference System
  • AOJ: Angle On Jam
  • ASE: Allowable Steering Error
  • BMR: Bullet Maximum Range
  • CC: Central Computer
  • DTWS: Designated Track-While-Scan
  • FCP: Front Cockpit
  • FNL: Funnel
  • FOV: Field of View
  • GDS: Gun Director Sight
  • HOJ: Home On Jam
  • HPRF: High Pulse Repetition Frequency
  • HUD: Head-Up Display
  • INS: Inertial Navigation System
  • INST: Instrument
  • INVARM: Invalid Armament
  • JAM: Jamming
  • LCOS: Lead Computing Optical Sight
  • LOS: Line of Sight
  • LSG: Losing
  • MEM: Memory
  • MPDP: Multipurpose Display Processor
  • MPRF: Medium Pulse Repetition Frequency
  • MRM: Medium Range Missile
  • NAV: Navigation
  • NGS: Nose Gear Steering
  • PACS: Programmable Armament Control Set
  • PDT: Primary Designated Target
  • R: Radar Range
  • RATR: Round At Target Range
  • RCS: Radar Cross Section
  • Rmin LC/HC: R minimum, low/high confidence
  • Rmax LC/HC: R maximum, low/high confidence
  • SBR: Special Burst Ranging
  • SRM: Short Range Missile
  • STT: Single Target Track
  • T: Training Mode
  • TD: Target Designator
  • TM: Target Mach
  • TOF: Time Of Flight (AIM-7, AIM-9)
  • TTA: Time To Active (AIM-120)
  • TTI: Time To Impact (AIM-120)
  • UNC: Uncage
  • VI: Visual Identification

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: This workbook (AAW-6) focuses on the characteristics, operation, and employment procedures of the F-15E's M61A1 gun system.

docs.title: Contents
docs.text:
• Introduction
  • Criterion Referenced Objectives (CROs)
  • Student Preparation Requirements
  • Text
  • End of Text Quiz
  • Glossary

docs.title: Criterion Referenced Objectives (CROs)
docs.text:
1. Identify the major components of the M61A1 gun system and their operational characteristics.
  2. Identify the differences between 20mm rounds and how to program them.
  3. Identify the general characteristics of the F-15E gunsight.
  4. Identify M61A1 gun employment techniques.
  5. Identify the general characteristics of the combined (gun/missile) mode.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• TO 1F-15E-34-1-1:
    • Section I: Gun Employment
    • Section II: Exterior Inspection (Gun), Gun Attack
  • AFTTP 3-1 Vol IV:
    • Air-to-Air Weapons (Gun)
    • Weapons Selection/Fire doctrine (20mm Gun Employment)

docs.title: Student Preparation Requirements
docs.text:
Before Class:

  1. Study this workbook and complete the End of Text Quiz. Bring this workbook to class.
  2. Read the applicable references in TO 1F-15E-34-1-1 and AFTTP 3-1, Vol IV.
  3. Review the RDR-3 workbook (suggested).
  4. Bring TO 1F-15E-34-1-1CL-1 (Dash 34 checklist) and this workbook to class.

docs.title: M61A1 Gun Description
docs.text:
• Type: Air-cooled, six-barrel Gatling gun.
  • Firing Rate: Selectable (4,000 or 6,000 rounds per minute).
  • Mechanism: Rotary action contained within a fixed rear housing.
  • Components: Six bolts, firing cam path, clearing cam path, rotating barrel cluster.
  • Location: Right wing root.
  • Cant Angle: 2° up from the FRL (Fuselage Reference Line).
  • Dispersion: 8 mils.

docs.title: Major System Components
docs.text:
• Gun
  • Ammunition container
  • Conveyor assemblies
  • Hydraulic power and gearbox assemblies

docs.title: 20mm Ammunition
docs.text:
• Components: Brass cartridge case, electric primer, propellant powder, projectile (Figure D-1).

[Figure D-1: 20mm Ammunition]

  • Firing Sequence:

    1. Electrical pulse applied to the primer.
    2. Primer flame ignites the propellant through a gas vent.
    3. Burning propellant creates gas that propels the projectile out of the barrel.

  • Muzzle Velocity:

    • M-56: 3,300 FPS (feet per second).
    • PGU-28: 3,375 FPS.

docs.title: TP (Target Practice)/TP-T (Tracer)
docs.text:
• M55A1/M55A2 (TP): Hollow, steel projectiles used for practice.
  • M220 (TP-T): Same as M55, but with a tracer.

docs.title: API (Armor Piercing Incendiary)
docs.text:
• M53: Steel projectile with an incendiary composition, used against armored targets.
  • Function: Combined penetration and incendiary effects.
  • Fuze: None (incendiary initiated by impact).

docs.title: HEI/HEI-T (Tracer)
docs.text:
• M56 (HEI): High-explosive incendiary cartridge used against aircraft and light material targets (Figure D-2).

[Figure D-2: HEI Cartridge]

  • Function: Combined detonation and incendiary effects upon impact.
  • Fuze: Mechanical point-detonating system with an aluminum cover (crushes on impact).
  • Arming:
    1. In-barrel: Acceleration and friction forces on the ball rotor and c-ring prevent detonator movement.
    2. Muzzle exit: Decreased acceleration and projectile spin rate (> 49,800 RPM) cause the c-ring to open due to centrifugal force.
    3. Detonator aligns with the firing pin and booster charge (arming complete 20-35 feet from the aircraft).
  • Explosion Delay: 300 milliseconds (allows for penetration of truck-type targets).

docs.title: PGU-27/B TP (Target Practice)
docs.text:
• Replacement: For the M55 cartridge.
  • Composition: Inert projectile with a steel body and solid aluminum alloy nose (Figure D-3).
  • Propellant: WC867 (modified version of the WC872).

[Figure D-3: PGU-27B TP Projectile]

  • Advantages:
    • Reduced drag (~33%).
    • Increased velocity (36% at 1,000 meters).
    • Decreased time of flight (39% at 1,000 meters).
  • Compatibility: No changes required to the gun, ammo handling, or storage equipment.

docs.title: PGU-28/B SAPHEI (Semi-Armor Piercing High Explosive Incendiary)
docs.text:
• Replacement: For the M56 HEI projectile.
  • Composition: Machined from 15B27 steel bar stock and hardened for improved performance against lightly armored targets (Figure D-4).
  • Components: Two incendiary compounds, high explosive, zirconium pellet, copper rotating band, aluminum nose and support disk.

[Figure D-4: PGU-28/B SAPHEI Projectile]

  • Function:
    1. Impact: Type I nose incendiary ignites.
    2. Nose incendiary ignites the Type II body incendiary.
    3. Body incendiary initiates the high explosive.
    4. Delay from burning pyrotechnic material allows for target penetration.
    5. High explosive detonation splinters the projectile body and ignites the zirconium pellet, providing a sustained spark for improved fire-starting.

docs.title: Ammunition Container
docs.text:
• Location: Center fuselage.
  • Capacity: 485 rounds.
  • Functions:
    • Stores ammunition.
    • Transfers rounds to the conveyor.
    • Receives spent casings and unfired rounds.

[Figure D-5: Gun]

docs.title: Conveyor
docs.text:
• Function: Transfers rounds to the feeder and returns spent casings/unfired rounds to the container.
  • Capacity: 69 rounds (total system capacity: 504 rounds).

docs.title: Gearbox and Power Supply
docs.text:
• Gearbox:

    • Uses hydraulic power to drive the conveyor.
    • Powers the unload drive assembly.

  • Power Supply:

    • Mounted on the gearbox.
    • Driven by Utility B hydraulic system.
    • Provides power for up to 6,000 RPM firing rate.
    • Provides braking during gun deceleration.

  • Spin Up Time: 0.4 seconds.

docs.title: Conditions for Firing
docs.text:
• Gun externally preflighted "hot".
  • Landing gear handle up.
  • Master arm switch in ARM.
  • PACS not in a training mode.
  • Trigger squeezed to the second detent.

Caution: The weapon select switch doesn't need to be in GUN to fire the gun.

docs.title: Sequence
docs.text:
1. Round Pickup: Bolts engage rounds in the main cam path.
  2. Chambering: Rounds chambered as the bolts move forward in the firing cam path.
  3. Locking and Firing: Bolt locks into place, firing voltage applied.
  4. Extraction: Bolt unlocks and extracts the fired round.
  5. Ejection: Spent round ejected into the unload drive assembly.

docs.title: Trigger Release
docs.text:
1. Voltage Maintenance: Round fire and counting voltage remain active until hydraulic braking slows the gun.
  2. Delayed Shut Off: 5-11 rounds may fire after trigger release.
  3. Bolt Lock: All six bolts lock in the cleared position when the gun decelerates through 3,900 ± 150 RPM.
  4. Live Round Return: 6-9 live rounds clear the gun and return to the ammunition container.
  5. Total Stop Time: Slightly under 1 second.

docs.title: Rounds Limit Switch, Limit Counter, and Totalizer
docs.text:
• Location: Bottom of the ammunition container.
  • Functions:
    • Safing
    • Limiting the number of rounds processed.

[Figure D-6: Gun Control and Load]

  • Totalizer (1): Records the total number of rounds fired over the system's lifespan.

docs.title: Rounds Limit Switch (3)
docs.text:
• RDS LIMIT Setting (Limit Count ≤ 799): Controls rounds fired per sortie.
  • Clearing Cycle Initiation: Triggered when the preset round count is reached.
  • Overshoot: Up to 20 additional rounds may be fired at full rate.
  • Hydraulic Safing: Gun is hydraulically safe after limiter shutdown (limit count in the 979-999 range).
  • HUD Rounds Count: Displays "XXX" to indicate limit/total rounds expended.
  • RDS LIMIT (Limit Count 800-999): Gun is hydraulically safe.
  • NO LIMIT Setting: Only the armament ground safety pin and cam holdback tool/download pin prevent firing when the trigger is pulled.

docs.title: Hydraulic Manual Control Handle (4)
docs.text: • Stowed Position (Flush): Indicates the gun is not in load mode and is ready for firing.

docs.title: Type Ammo (5)
docs.text: • Verification: Observe at the load gate and compare to AFTO Form 781A (refer to AFTO Form 781H for the correct page/block).

docs.title: Load Gate Tangs/Cartridge Guide Tangs (6)
docs.text:
• Proper Positioning: Essential for ammo feeding.
  • Separation: Occurs during loading.
  • Post-Load: Positioned tips-to-tips to provide a smooth ammo path.

docs.title: Armament Ground Safety Pin (1, Figure D-7)
docs.text:
• Function: Interrupts firing voltage to the rounds.

[Figure D-7: Gun Safing]

docs.title: Cam Clearing Holdback Tool/Download Pin (2, Figure D-7)
docs.text: • Function: Mechanically holds the cam open to prevent chambering.

docs.title: Last Round Switch
docs.text:
• Location: Hand-off unit in the feed system.
  • Function: Senses casings and projectiles.
  • Clearing Cycle Initiation: Triggered when two consecutive empty casings are detected. Also disables gun motor power.
  • Purpose: Prevents damage from attempting to chamber a spent round.

docs.title: Cold Gun Safing
docs.text:
• Procedure: Ensures the M61A1 is electrically, hydraulically, and mechanically safe.
  • Reference: Refer to earlier sections for procedures.
  • Dash 34 Checklist: Verify all items.

Important: If you have any questions or concerns about the weapon, consult a specialist.

docs.title: Hot Gun Inspection Sequence
docs.text:
1. Ammo type and quantity.
  2. Armament ground safety pin (installed).
  3. Gun clearing sector tool/download pin (not installed).
  4. Rounds limit counter (set as required).
  5. Rounds limit switch (check and set).

Note: If the limit counter is set above 799 with the limit switch in LIMIT, the gun will not fire.

  1. Hydraulic manual control handle (stowed position).
  2. Load gate and cartridge guide tangs (properly positioned).

Caution: Ensure load gate arms latch around the load gate slide tangs for proper gun system function.

docs.title: Cold Gun Inspection Sequence
docs.text:
1. Ammo loaded (as required).
  2. Armament ground safety pin (installed inside out).
  3. Gun clearing sector tool/download pin (installed).
  4. Rounds limit counter (set to 900).
  5. Rounds limit switch (RDS LIMIT).
  6. Hydraulic manual control handle (stowed position).

docs.title: Ammo Type and Quantity (Figure D-8)
docs.text:
• Programming: The A/A weapon load page allows for selecting both bullet type and quantity.

[Figure D-8: Load]

  • Quantity: Loaded using PB #1 and #2.

  • Bullet Type:

    • Displayed under PB #20 (PGU-28 or M-56).
    • Toggle selection with PB #20.
    • Can also be set at the AFMSS (Air Force Mission Support System) and entered via DTM (Data Transfer Module).

  • Counters: Displayed values on the PACS and HUD are for informational purposes only and don't affect gun arming/dearming.

Note: Incorrect programming can cause significant errors in gunsight calculations.

docs.title: Rounds Remaining Display (Figure D-9)
docs.text:
• Format: Round count followed by a "P" for PGU-28 or "M" for M-56 (except on the HUD, where type is not indicated).

[Figure D-9: Round Count Displayed]

  • Training Mode: The last digit in the PACS and HUD bullet count is replaced by a "T" when A/A TRNG is selected.

docs.title: Modes
docs.text:
• Gun Director Sight (GDS): Accurate, all-aspect gunsight.
  • Funnel (FNL): Backup gunsight, allows for target range estimation by comparing wingspan to funnel width (accurate within certain limitations).

Note:

  • Radar Tracking: Radar in single target track (STT).
  • Gun Tracking: Pilot tracks the target using HUD aiming symbology.

docs.title: Functionality
docs.text:
• Accurate Aiming: Eliminates the need for steady-state tracking.

  • Reticle Display: Appears after:

    • Final radar track with JEM (Jet Engine Modulation) resolved.
    • 1.5 second settling time delay.
    • Valid data for computation.

  • Computations: CC (Central Computer) factors in:

    • Target velocities and accelerations.
    • Estimated future target position.
    • Bullet trajectory and target dynamics.

docs.title: Advantages
docs.text:
• Eliminates Lead Anticipation: No need to fire early to compensate for bullet TOF (Time of Flight).
  • No Steady-State Tracking Required: Accurate reticle aiming even without a stable pipper on target. However, higher hit probability is achieved with a shorter TOF and low target LOS (Line of Sight) rates.

docs.title: Director Mode Software (GDS Algorithm)
docs.text: • Lead Angle Computation: Uses radar data and is independent of F-15E maneuvering/accelerations, allowing for rapid aiming and minimal impact from attitude changes.

docs.title: Reticle Motion
docs.text:
• Undampened: Reticle motion reflects actual bullet stream dynamics.
  • Stiffen Selection (GDS or GDS Funnel):
    • Reverts to LCOS track funnel display with the LCOS reticle positioned at radar target range.
    • Uses 1,000 feet for range and/or -50 FPS for range rate if those values are unavailable.

docs.title: Assumptions
docs.text:
• F-15E can out-turn opponents and establish a tracking position.
  • F-15E is in the target's plane of motion (POM) with ≤ 45° angle-off.
  • F-15E and target are pulling the same G-load.

docs.title: Functionality
docs.text:
• Lead Computing Optical Sight (LCOS) Algorithm: Used for calculations, relying primarily on ownship data (except for radar range/range rate when available).
  • Dynamic Response: Funnel reacts to changes in F-15E acceleration.
  • Accuracy: Dependent on the availability and quality of radar data.

docs.title: Funnel Display
docs.text:
• Center: Corresponds to pseudo LCOS reticles.
  • Width: Represents a 40-foot wingspan target at seven computed ranges (750, 1,000, 1,250, 1,500, 2,250, 4,000, and 5,000 feet).
  • End Limit: Limited to bullet maximum range when less than 5,000 feet.
  • No Radar Track: Three 2-mil pippers are displayed at 1,000, 2,250, and 4,000 feet (PGU-28) or at 1,000 and 2,250 feet (M56).

docs.title: Aiming with the Funnel
docs.text:
• Pilot's Task: Maneuver the target within the funnel at the correct range for a firing solution.
  • Range Estimation: Use the funnel width (representing a 40-foot wingspan) to estimate target range.
  • Usage:
    • Tracking Reference: Stabilize the appropriate section of the funnel on the target and fire (maintain constant G for a stable sight picture).
    • Dampened Bullet Position Indicator:
      • Fly to create a common intercept point between the target and funnel (at the correct range).
      • Fire when the funnel center is approximately one TOF plus gun spin-up time from the intercept.

docs.title: Display Options
docs.text:
• LCOS Search Funnel
  • LCOS Track Funnel
  • GDS
  • GDS Funnel

Selection Factors: Radar track status, funnel selection, combined mode status.

docs.title: Gunsight Display Selection (Figure D-10)
docs.text: [Figure D-10: Gunsight Display Selection]

docs.title: LCOS Search Funnel (Figure D-11)
docs.text:
• Conditions: GUN selected, radar in search mode.
  • Only No-Lock Gun Display: Provides aiming assistance without radar lock-on.
  • Funnel Representation: Simulated bullet stream emanating from the F-15E (dynamically adjusts during maneuvering).
  • Top of Funnel: Closer ranges.
  • Bottom of Funnel: Maximum ranges.

docs.title: Pippers and RATR
docs.text:
• Pippers: Three 2-mil circles at 1,000, 2,250, and 4,000 feet aiming ranges.
  • Funnel Width: Based on the apparent size of a 40-foot wingspan target at the corresponding range.
  • Tracking Solution: Place a pipper on the target, visually confirm the range, and fire.
  • RATR (Rounds At Target Range) Cue:
    • Inverted triangle showing where bullets will impact at a pseudo target range of 2,250 feet (1,000 feet if stiffened).
    • With radar lock-on: Indicates bullet impact location at radar-derived target range.
    • Displayed from first bullet arrival until the last bullet in the burst.
    • Not HUD-limited (won't be displayed if computed position is outside the FOV).

docs.title: Rounds Remaining Display
docs.text:
• Indication: Approximate number of rounds loaded and not yet fired.
  • Decrement: Decreases by 10 during firing.

docs.title: LCOS Track Funnel (Figure D-12)
docs.text:
• Conditions: GUN selected, radar has achieved lock-on.
  • Display Duration: Until stable radar STT (Single Target Track) is achieved, after which the GDS or GDS FNL display is shown (based on the last selection).

docs.title: Reticle and Funnel Movement
docs.text:
• Reticle: 2-mil pipper and 25-mil segmented circle.
  • Positioning: Based on radar target range/range rate and ownship maneuvering parameters. Uses 2,250 feet for range (or 1,000 feet if stiffened) and 50 FPS for range rate if those values are invalid.

docs.title: Tracking Solution
docs.text: Hold the pipper on the target in a stable tracking situation and fire (bullets should impact after one TOF).

docs.title: Range Bar
docs.text:
• Analog "Clock" Format: Shows radar-derived range.
  • Movement: Starts at 12 o'clock and moves clockwise.
  • Range Reading: Leading edge indicates range in thousands of feet.

docs.title: GDS (Figure D-13)
docs.text:
• Conditions: GUN selected (or combined mode), full radar lock-on.
  • Toggling: Use the FCP coolie switch to switch between GDS and GDS FNL displays.
  • "GDS" Display: Appears in HUD window 17.
  • Aiming: Place the pipper on the target and fire (assuming within effective range).

docs.title: Turn Plane Line
docs.text:
• Function: Represents the CC's projection of the target's POM (Plane of Motion). Aids in achieving an in-plane solution during high-aspect gun attacks.
  • Display: Line drawn from the gun cross, through the reticle, to the HUD edge.

docs.title: Range Bar and BMR
docs.text:
• Range Bar: Functions as previously described.

  • BMR (Bullet Maximum Range) Cue:

    • Dynamically positioned dot on the 50-mil reticle perimeter.
    • Indicates maximum effective range based on loaded round type and ownship/target maneuvering/relationship.
    • Range reading: Same as range bar.
    • If exceeding 12,000 feet: Limited to the 12 o'clock position.

  • Maximum Accurate Firing Range: Achieved when the range bar tab aligns with the BMR cue or is shorter.

docs.title: TD Box Removal/Reappearance
docs.text:
• Removed: When its center is within 25 mils of the pipper and the target range is less than 3,000 feet (or the maximum bullet range, whichever is greater).
  • Reappears: When the range increases to 3,200 feet (or 200 feet beyond the maximum bullet range), or when the box center is more than 37 mils from the pipper.

docs.title: GDS Funnel (Figure D-14)
docs.text:
• Conditions: GUN mode, radar has achieved single target track.
  • Display: Combines GDS reticle and LCOS track funnel displays (turn plane line is replaced by the funnel).
  • "FNL" Display: Appears in HUD window 17 when GDS Funnel is active.
  • Dual Solutions: Provides two aiming solutions (GDS and LCOS).

docs.title: Firing Rate
docs.text:
• HIGH: Greater bullet stream density and higher Pk (probability of kill). Provides approximately 5 seconds of continuous fire at 100 rounds per second.
  • A/A Combat: Fire in 1-2 second bursts to increase bullet density near the target.

docs.title: Trigger Release Delay
docs.text: Remember the ~1 second delay between trigger release and gun stoppage (clearing cycle). Avoid pulling the trigger again during this period.

docs.title: Long Range Shot Considerations
docs.text:
• Increased TOF: Gives the target more time to maneuver and avoid the bullet stream.
  • Error Potential: Avoid firing at near-maximum range.

docs.title: PGU-28 Advantages
docs.text:
• Increased Effective Range: Due to higher muzzle velocity and lower drag.
  • Reduced Lead Requirement: Compared to the M-56.

docs.title: LCOS Search Display (Figure D-15)
docs.text:
• Conditions: No radar lock-on.
  • Range Estimation: Crucial. Use funnel width (representing a 40-foot wingspan) as a guide.
  • Target Placement: Position the target within the funnel where its wingspan matches the funnel width for a good firing solution (adjust aiming based on actual wingspan).

docs.title: Shot Approach Options
docs.text:
• Pull the target down through the funnel until a wingspan match is achieved.
  • Position your nose ahead of the target and guide them into position from the bottom of the funnel.

Firing Timing: Initiate one TOF before the funnel/wingspan match, especially if the target is not in a stable tracking position.

docs.title: LCOS Track Display (Figure D-16)
docs.text:
• Conditions: Radar lock-on.

  • Effective Envelope:

    • Aspect ≤ 45°.
    • Closure ≤ 30 knots.
    • In target POM.
    • Constant G-load.

  • Aiming: Track the target with the pipper (wingspan/funnel matching not required).

docs.title: Pipper Considerations
docs.text:
• Accuracy: Pipper on target doesn't guarantee bullet impact, especially in high aspect/closure situations where the sight may under-lead.
  • Out-of-Plane Target: The pipper will lag until shooter parameters stabilize.
  • Increasing G: Can depress the pipper and indicate a need for more lead. Avoid adding G and firing simultaneously (results in bullets trailing the target).

docs.title: GDS Display (Figure D-17)
docs.text:
• Aiming: Place the pipper on the target and fire (within BMR range).
  • Tracking Time: Extended tracking is not required.

docs.title: GDS FNL Display (Figure D-18)
docs.text:
• Aiming: Place the pipper on the target and fire (within BMR range).
  • Funnel: Aids in shot alignment.
  • Tracking Time: Extended tracking not required.

docs.title: GDS and GDS FNL: Tracking vs. Snapshot
Considerations
docs.text:
• Energy state
  • Threat environment
  • Maneuvering requirements
  • Timing

docs.title: Tracking Shots
docs.text:
• Advantages: High Pk.
  • Disadvantages: Time-consuming, energy-intensive, predictable F-15E flight path.

docs.title: Snapshot
docs.text:
• Advantages: Conserves energy, allows for quick separation if unsuccessful.
  • Disadvantage: Lower Pk.

docs.title: GDS/GDS FNL Tracking Shot
docs.text:
1. Initialization: Wait ~1.5 seconds after radar lock-on for GDS initialization (LCOS track display will be shown during this period).
  2. Lead: Pull sufficient lead (reticle ahead of target) and use the turn plane line/funnel to establish an in-plane solution.
  3. Controlled Rate: Allow the pipper to move towards the target at a manageable rate.
  4. Fire: When within range, keeping the pipper on the target as needed.
  5. RATR Confirmation: Should appear over the target one TOF after trigger pull.

docs.title: GDS/GDS FNL Snapshot
docs.text:
1. Lead Establishment:
    • More lead brings the target closer at firing range and reduces TOF, but can obscure over-the-nose visibility.
    • A slight out-of-plane pursuit course is acceptable for maintaining visual contact.
    • Use the turn plane line/funnel to guide both in-plane and slightly out-of-plane maneuvers.
  2. POM Alignment: Reposition into the target's POM as range decreases and the target tracks forward.
  3. Firing Decision:
    • Advantage: Direct indication of bullet miss distance (no dampening or maneuver-induced delays).
    • Lag:
      • None due to fighter maneuvering.
      • Up to 2 seconds due to target jinking (caused by radar tracking filter lag).

docs.title: LCOS Search/Track Funnel Snapshot
docs.text:
• Firing Point: Determined by the track rate of the funnel match/pipper and the target towards each other.
  • Stable Parameters: Fire one TOF before the pipper/target intercept.
  • Increased G (LOS Rate Adjustment): The pipper will depress towards the target and be out of solution. Open fire earlier to compensate. Cease fire once the pipper passes through the target (avoid wasting ammo and delaying repositioning/separation).

[Figure D-19: Snap Shot]

docs.title: Shot Criteria
docs.text:
Refer to Table D-1 for current F-15 gun shot criteria (AFTTP 3-1, Volume 1, Change 1, 17 Mar 98).

[Table D-1: Gun Shot Criteria]

docs.title: Conversion Methodology
docs.text: The following explanation details how the Joint Munitions Effectiveness Manual (JMEM) 20-round requirement translates into RATR (Rounds at Target Range) frame counts for both 3/4-inch and 8mm VTR (Video Tape Recorder).

docs.title: Assumptions
docs.text:
• Bullet Dispersion: The F-15 gun has ≤ 4 mils of dispersion (80% of bullets within a 4-foot cone at 1,000 feet).
  • Published Dispersion: 8 mils (accounts for boresight error, radar track latency, scintillation, other aircraft factors).
  • Valid RATR Frame: Any frame where the center of the RATR touches the aircraft (up to 50% of the RATR can be off the aircraft at any given time).
  • Average Hit Percentage: ~40%.

docs.title: 3/4-inch VTR and 8mm Assessment
docs.text:
To achieve a JMEM-compliant 20-round hit:

  • Required Time on Target: 0.75 seconds.

  • Frame Counts:

    • 3/4-inch VTR (60 FPS): 30 frames.
    • 8mm (30 FPS): 15 frames.

  • Full RATR on Target: Reduces required frames due to higher hit probability (15 frames for 3/4-inch VTR, 8 frames for 8mm).

  • Two-Frame Count: Any frame where the entire RATR is on the target and its center is on the fuselage counts as two frames. This acknowledges the increased hit probability, ensures bullet density on vital aircraft components, and factors in the improved survivability of 4th generation aircraft to PGU rounds hitting the wings.

docs.title: Shot Definitions
docs.text:
• Gun Attempt: Any trigger pull.
  • Valid Gun Shot: Any attempt resulting in at least one frame with the RATR center on the target.
  • Invalid Gun Shot: Any attempt resulting in no frames with the RATR center on target due to shooter error (plane, range, lead, etc.).
  • Defeated Gun Shot: Any attempt resulting in no frames with the RATR center on target due to successful target evasion (jinking, out-of-plane maneuvers, etc.).

docs.title: Double Generator/Utility B Failure
docs.text: Electrical and hydraulic power loss disables the gun.

docs.title: ADC/INS Failure
docs.text:
• Reversion: Gunsight reverts to FNL backup mode.
  • Complete INS Failure: Results in a fixed, depressed gunsight. Enter the desired mil depression angle in the UFC.

docs.title: PACS Failure
docs.text:
• Gun Function: An armed gun will fire.
  • Limitations:
    • Unable to change firing rate or monitor/adjust rounds count.
    • No gun reticles on the HUD.

docs.title: CC Failure
docs.text:
• Gun Cross: Continuously displayed (if master arm is in ARM).
  • Aiming: Gun cross becomes the sole reference (Figure D-20).

[Figure D-20: Gun CC Failure]

docs.title: Functionality
docs.text:
• Allows simultaneous use of the gunsight and gun while SRM (Short Range Missile) is selected.
  • Radar display behaves as if in SRM mode.
  • Gun mode symbology takes priority on the HUD, with limited SRM data added.
  • HUD reverts to primary gun mode upon firing.

docs.title: Combined Mode Entry
docs.text:
1. Select SRM on the weapon select switch.
  2. Pull up on the FCP coolie switch for more than 1 second.

Preconditions:

  • A/A master mode selected.
  • Pilot in command of the A/A radar.
  • SRM selected.
  • Any radar mode except TWS (Track-While-Scan).
  • Gun rounds available.

TWS Exclusion: Prevents conflict with the coolie switch function.

SRM Availability: Not required for combined mode entry.

GDS/GDS FNL Toggling: Activate the coolie switch up for less than 1 second while in combined mode.

docs.title: Combined Mode Exit
docs.text:
Triggered by:

  • Holding the coolie switch up for longer than 1 second.
  • Exiting A/A master mode.
  • Moving the weapon select switch out of SRM.
  • Changing radar mode to TWS.
  • Firing the last gun round (after its TOF has expired).
  • Loss of PACS-to-CC communication.

docs.title: HUD Displays (Combined Mode)
docs.text:
• Normal Gun Mode Displays
  • Limited SRM Symbology:
    • SRM Rmin LC/HC, Rmax LC/HC
    • SRM shoot cue
    • SRM uncage cue
    • AIM-9M seeker head position circle

docs.title: Symbols Not Displayed (Combined Mode)
docs.text:
• Waterline
  • ASE circle
  • Steering dot
  • SRM analog range bar
  • AIM-9M FOV circle
  • Break X
  • No zone cue
  • Target locator line
  • Degrees off boresight
  • Degrees before break-lock

docs.title: Combined Mode Gunsight Displays
docs.text:
• Radar Search: LCOS search funnel.
  • Radar STT:
    • Stiffen: LCOS track funnel.
    • No Stiffen: GDS or GDS FNL (based on selection).

docs.title: Stiffen (Combined Mode)
docs.text:
• Coolie Switch Held Down: Commands both missile boresight and LCOS track funnel gunsight (Figure D-21, assuming radar STT and AIM-9M is caged).

[Figure D-21: Combined, STT, Stiffen LCOS Selected, Boresight SRM]

docs.title: AIM-9M HUD Displays (Combined Mode)
docs.text:
• Seeker Circle: Present, but FOV circle is not displayed (no indication of SCAN mode).
  • Radar Search: Seeker circle is at the boresight position (Figure D-22).

[Figure D-22: Combined, Radar in Search]

docs.title: Uncaged Seeker Circle
docs.text:
• SBR (Special Burst Ranging): Commanded when the seeker is uncaged.

  • Data Display (Figure D-23):

    • Range scale
    • Target range caret
    • Vc (closure velocity)

  • Data Duration: 3 seconds.

  • Additional SBRs: Triggered by pressing the laser fire button (FCP).
  • Not Displayed During SBR: Rmax (LC/HC), Rmin (LC/HC), and the shoot cue.

[Figure D-23: Radar in Search, Uncaged SRM, SBR]

docs.title: Radar Lock-On
docs.text:
• Display (Figure D-24):
    • Rmax (LC/HC) and Rmin (LC/HC) displayed when AIM-9M and radar LOS are within 2°.
    • Shoot cue displayed (and flashing) if within launch parameters.
    • TD box displayed.

[Figure D-24: AIM-9M Shoot Cue]

docs.title: TD Box Occlusion (Figure D-25)
docs.text:
• Condition: TD box is removed due to close proximity to the gunsight.
  • Shoot Cue: Displayed flashing at the top or bottom of the seeker position circle when the TD box is hidden.

[Figure D-25: STT, Uncaged SRM, TD Box Occluded]

docs.title: Off-Missile Cue
docs.text:
• Radar STT: Replaces round count (Figure D-26).
  • Gun Firing: Round count replaces the off-missile cue until the trigger is released.

[Figure D-26: STT, Off-Missile, Uncaged SRM, Shoot Cue]

docs.title: Inside Rmin LC
docs.text:
• No Break X: The break X symbol is not displayed when the target is within Rmin LC (minimum range, low confidence).
  • SRM Symbology: Remains, but the shoot cue, SRM count, and type are removed.
  • No Zone Cue: Also not displayed (Figure D-27).

[Figure D-27: STT, Inside SRM Minimum Range, Caged SRM, GDS]

docs.title: Gun HUD Displays (Combined Mode)
docs.text:
• Full Functionality: All normal gun mode displays are available.
  • SBR: The LCOS search funnel is displayed, but SBR data is not used for gunsight computations.

docs.title: Trigger Activation (Combined Mode)
docs.text:
• Removed: SRM shoot cue and AIM-9M seeker head position circle (Figure D-28).
  • Displayed: Rmax (LC/HC), Rmin (LC/HC), SRM count, rounds remaining (replaces off-missile cue if applicable).
  • Priority: Gunsight symbology until trigger release or all rounds are expended.
  • RATR: Appears after one TOF if within the HUD FOV.

[Figure D-28: STT, Trigger Activated]

docs.title: Trigger Release
docs.text:
• Restored: SRM symbology (except for the shoot cue).
  • Shoot Cue Reappearance: After the last bullet's TOF is complete and the RATR is removed.
  • Last Round Fired: Combined mode automatically exits to SRM after the last round's TOF and RATR removal.

docs.title: A/A Radar Display (Combined Mode)
docs.text: • Display Elements: Shoot cue, Rmax (LC/HC), and Rmin (LC/HC) are displayed under the same conditions as on the HUD.

docs.title: HUD Window 5 (Combined Mode)
docs.text:
Table D-2 details the HUD window 5 displays for combined/SRM/GUN operation.

[Table D-2: Combined Mode HUD]

docs.title: End of Text Quiz
docs.text:
1. The M61A1 is hydraulically driven by the ___ system.

    • a. Utility A
    • b. Utility B
    • c. PC-1B
    • d. PC-2B

  2. The RATR symbol should be used as the primary gun aiming device.

    • a. True
    • b. False

  3. The funnel (LCOS algorithm) assumes ___.

    • a. your aircraft is within 45° of the target’s tail.
    • b. fighter G equals target G.
    • c. target parameters will not change during bullet TOF.
    • d. All of the above.

  4. In radar search, the LCOS search funnel width is based on a 40-foot wingspan aircraft.

    • a. True
    • b. False

  5. The bullet maximum range cue with PGU-28 loaded ___.

    • a. fluctuates as flight parameters change.
    • b. is not present with CC failure.
    • c. indicates a bullet TOF of 2.5 seconds.
    • d. All of the above.

  6. The radar range to the target aircraft in Figure F-1 below is roughly ___.

    • a. 1,000 feet.
    • b. 4,000 feet.
    • c. 3,000 feet.
    • d. 2,000 feet.

[Figure F-1: Radar Range]

  1. Which of the following statements about the M-61 gun is (are) true?

    • a. A double main generator failure disables the gun.
    • b. The installed armament ground safety pin prevents firing voltage from reaching the chambered rounds.
    • c. The hydraulic manual control handle must be stowed (flush) for gun employment.
    • d. All of the above.

  2. In radar STT, with combined mode selected (SRM caged), holding the coolie switch down in the front seat ___.

    • a. only boresights the AIM-9M seeker circle.
    • b. stiffens the GDS sight.
    • c. commands a programming LCOS.
    • d. boresights the AIM-9M seeker circle and commands LCOS track funnel.

  3. The combined mode may be entered with SRM selected in all the following radar modes except ___.

    • a. standby.
    • b. search.
    • c. STT.
    • d. TWS.

  4. In the combined mode, special burst ranging target data is displayed for ___ seconds.

    • a. 1
    • b. 2
    • c. 3
    • d. 4

docs.text: No formal ACG phase review is scheduled, but instructors are available to answer questions and assist with material review.

docs.title: Learning Responsibility
docs.text:
• Student-Driven: You are primarily responsible for mastering the material.
  • Instructor Support: Available to guide and answer questions.
  • Avionics Block (CBT): Given the emphasis on CBT, maximize the limited classroom, flight, and simulator time by completing all pre-study requirements.

docs.title: F-15E Roles and Capabilities
docs.text:
• Dual Role Fighter: Designed for both air-to-ground (A/G) and air-to-air (A/A) missions.
  • High Performance: Supersonic, all-weather capable.

docs.title: Air-to-Ground Role
docs.text:
• Conventional Strike: Employs both general purpose and precision-guided munitions.
  • Nuclear Strike: Capable of delivering nuclear ordnance.
  • All-Weather Penetration: Can penetrate and deliver weapons in adverse weather conditions.

docs.title: Air-to-Air Role
docs.text:
• Self-Escort
  • Air Base Defense
  • Design Features: Long station times, excellent dash and turning performance.

docs.title: Configurations, Range, and Capabilities
docs.text:
• Key Features:

    • Superior payload/radius characteristics.
    • Flexible payload options.
    • High-speed, low-level penetration capability.
    • Excellent combat maneuverability.

  • Performance:

    • Mission radius: > 1,000 nm.
    • Penetration speed: 600 KTAS.
    • Sustained maneuvering: 4 Gs at military power, 6 Gs with afterburner.
    • Instantaneous maneuvering: Up to 9 Gs at gross weights of 68,000 lbs (achievable at sea level).

docs.title: Air-to-Ground Performance
docs.text:
• Payload/Radius Enhancement:
    • Fuel capacity: Up to 35,550 lbs.
    • Low drag from tangential weapon carriage on CFTs (Conformal Fuel Tanks).
  • Example Mission: 680 nm radius with a payload of four MK-84s and four AIM-120s (including a 100 nm sea-level dash).

  • Sea-Level Dash Speed:

    • 590 KTAS without external tanks.
    • 550 KTAS with tanks.

  • Nuclear Strike: ~1,100 nm radius (tanks jettisoned).

docs.title: Flexibility
docs.text:
• Store Stations: 19 integral stations.
  • Maximum Payload (Full Internal Fuel): 24,500 lbs.
  • A/A Missile Stations: 8.
  • Mission Tailoring: Allows commanders to match payload and radius to mission requirements.

docs.title: Air-to-Air Performance
docs.text:
• Maneuverability:
    • Equal to F-15C at subsonic speeds.
    • Superior to F-15C at supersonic speeds.
  • Instantaneous Maneuvering: Enhanced by a 9 G design limit load factor.

docs.title: Mission Examples
docs.text:
• Theater Air Defense: Up to 3.7 hours of CAP time at 200 nm from base with 8 missiles.
  • Area Intercept: 967 nm radius with 8 missiles.

docs.title: Ferry Mission
docs.text:
• Global Reach: Sufficient range for worldwide deployment without tanker support.
  • Ferry Range: ~2,200 nm with full external fuel and four AIM-120s.

docs.title: Design Philosophy
docs.text:
• Low-Risk Approach: Leveraged existing F-15 capabilities to meet USAF requirements for a survivable deep interdiction aircraft.
  • Modifications: Primarily focused on enhancing penetration and precision weapon delivery in all weather conditions, day or night.
  • Airframe/Systems: Relatively minor changes required.
  • Cockpit: Substantial modifications to accommodate LANTIRN (Low Altitude Navigation and Targeting Infrared for Night) and reduce crew workload.
  • Design Refinement: Many "changes" were already approved for the F-15A/C and represent system improvements rather than completely new developments.

docs.title: Cockpit Design
docs.text:
• Workload Reduction and Task Simplification: Key design goals.

  • Multiple Displays:

    • MPDs (Multipurpose Displays).
    • MPCDs (Multipurpose Color Displays).

    Provide simultaneous access to sensor, weapon, and advisory data, minimizing display sequencing.

  • Color Displays: Enhance data interpretation.

  • Integrated Upfront Control (UFC): For operating CNI (Communications, Navigation, and Identification) systems.
  • Hand Controllers: Enable quick mode changes, display option selection, and sensor/weapon management.
  • Ergonomics: Displays and controls are within easy reach and strategically positioned for optimal viewing.

docs.title: Display Operation
docs.text:
• Menu-Driven: Utilize prompting menus for sensor modes, submodes, and advisory formats.
  • System Integration: Cockpit controls, instrumentation, and displays are integrated for maximum operational flexibility.

docs.title: Crew Coordination
docs.text: Essential for managing the extensive cockpit flexibility. Develop a plan to avoid redundant efforts and ensure all tasks are completed.

docs.title: LANTIRN
docs.text:
• Composition: Two pods (navigation and targeting).

  • Capabilities:

    • Terrain Following Radar (TFR)
    • Forward Looking Infrared (FLIR)
    • Target detection, identification, and designation (day/night)
    • Target acquisition and track
    • Automatic target handoff to Maverick missiles

  • Integrated Radar Altimeter: Used for automatic terrain following and manual flight.

docs.title: F100-PW-220 Engine
docs.text:
• Replacement: For the F100-PW-100.
  • Advantages:
    • Easier maintenance.
    • Improved responsiveness.
    • Longer service life.
    • Computer-controlled for optimal performance.

docs.title: F100-PW-229 (IPE)
docs.text: • Aircraft: F-15Es with tail numbers 90-0233 and higher.

docs.title: Tactical Electronic Warfare System (TEWS)
docs.text:
• Components:
    • ALQ-135 Internal Countermeasures Set (ICS)
    • ALQ-128 Electronic Warfare Warning Set (EWWS)
    • ALR-56C Radar Warning Receiver (RWR)
    • ALE-45 Countermeasure Dispenser (CMD) set

docs.title: Inertial Navigation System (INS)
docs.text:
• Type: Self-contained, fully automatic ring laser gyro (RLG) system.

  • Functions:

    • Primary attitude reference.
    • Continuous present position (PP) monitoring.

  • Alignment Times:

    • Stored heading: 40 seconds.
    • Full: 4 minutes.

  • Accuracy: ~0.8 nm/hour.

  • Reliability: 2,000 hours MTBF (Mean Time Between Failure).
  • Power: Operable on emergency generator power.

docs.title: Retained Capabilities
docs.text: All F-15C air-to-air modes and capabilities.

docs.title: New A/G Modes
docs.text:
• High Resolution Map (HRM)
  • Real Beam Map (RBM)
  • Precision Velocity Update (PVU)

docs.title: High Resolution Map (HRM)
docs.text:
• Function: Accurate long-range designation and LANTIRN targeting pod cueing.
  • Resolution: 8.5 - 1,014 feet (depending on map size and range).
  • Availability:
    • Not available within 8° of the aircraft's velocity vector.
    • Available throughout the PPI (Plan Position Indicator) scan.

docs.title: Real Beam Map (RBM)
docs.text:
• Function: Rapid large-area mapping.
  • Capabilities:
    • Mapping along the velocity vector.
    • Backup targeting pod cueing (large, discrete targets).
    • Terrain feature display for low-altitude navigation assistance.
    • Weather detection (using manual antenna elevation control and pencil beam).

docs.title: Precision Velocity Update (PVU)
docs.text:
• Purpose: Refine ownship velocity estimate (more accurate than INS data).
  • Requirement: LANTIRN's narrow FOV requires velocity accuracy within 1 FPS for target designation from radar maps at ranges ≥ 10 nm.
  • Processing: Uses coherent Doppler processing in HRM mode to display target returns at the correct azimuth based on aircraft velocity.

docs.title: Missionized Cockpits
docs.text:
• Both Cockpits: Arranged to improve situational awareness and minimize workload.

  • Front Cockpit:

    • Two 6-inch MPDs.
    • One 5-inch MPCD.
    • UFC.
    • Integrated Engine Monitor Display (EMD).
    • Wide FOV HUD (WFOV HUD).

  • Rear Cockpit:

    • Two 6-inch MPDs.
    • Two 5-inch MPCDs.
    • UFC.

  • Display Flexibility: Either crew member can view displays controlled by the other.

docs.title: HOTAS (Hands On Throttle And Stick) Philosophy
docs.text: • Retained: From the F-15, implemented in both cockpits.

docs.title: Control Integration
docs.text:
• Menu-Driven Interface: Replaces traditional control panels, integrating system functions into display formats.
  • Example: Radar controls are now within the A/A radar display, eliminating the need for a dedicated panel.

docs.title: Additional Familiarization
docs.text:
• Instructor-Led: Provided in class.
  • References:
    • Foldouts 5 and 7 in the Dash 1.
    • Handout section of this workbook.

docs.title: Multipurpose Display Group
docs.text:
The F-15E cockpits have few dedicated controls and displays, relying primarily on MPDs and MPCDs for system access and data presentation (Figure D-3).

[Figure D-3: MPD/MPCD]

Note: MPDs and MPCDs are functionally similar, but the A/G radar cannot be displayed on MPCDs.

docs.title: Functionality
docs.text:
• Flexibility: Provide extensive crew flexibility.
  • Controls:
    • 20 peripheral pushbuttons for controlling aircraft/systems and displayed data.
    • Three rocker switches (function similarly to TV controls).
    • BIT (Built-In Test) indicator.

docs.title: Pushbuttons
docs.text: Referred to by number (e.g., PB #1) for convenience.

docs.title: Menu Items
docs.text: Displayed next to each pushbutton to indicate available modes and options.

docs.title: BIT Ball
docs.text: Turns white to indicate an internal system failure.

docs.title: Color Coding
docs.text:
• MPCDs: Use color coding to aid in data interpretation (e.g., EHSI, ADI).
  • Navigational Maps: Color displays improve situational awareness.

docs.title: Wide Field of View Head-Up Display (WFOV HUD)
Functions (Figure D-4)
docs.text:
[Figure D-4: WFOV HUD]

  • Primary Flight Instrument: Displays critical flight parameters:

    • Attitude
    • AOA (Angle of Attack)
    • Current/available G
    • Velocity vector (flight path marker)

  • Steering: Provides guidance for navigation and weapons delivery (based on selected master mode - A/A, A/G, NAV, INST).

  • Night Operations: Capable of displaying LANTIRN FLIR video.

docs.title: HUD Repeater
docs.text: Available on any front or rear cockpit display.

docs.title: Location
docs.text: One in each cockpit (Figure D-5).

docs.title: Functionality
docs.text:
• Primary Interface: Used to control most F-15E avionics systems and functions, replacing conventional switch panels.

[Figure D-5: UFC]

docs.title: Components
docs.text:
• LCD (Liquid Crystal Display) Screen:

    • 6 rows, 20 characters per row.
    • Top 4 rows: Menu/submenu options and data.
    • 5th Row: UHF manual frequency data.
    • 6th Row: Preset channel selections and scratchpad (data entered via the keyboard).

  • Option Pushbuttons: 10 buttons located on the sides of the LCD.

  • UHF Preset Channel Select Knobs: Adjacent to the corresponding scratchpad display.
  • UHF Volume Control Knobs: Below the channel select knobs.
  • Data Entry Keyboard: 20 keys (alphanumeric and special function).

docs.title: Controlled Systems/Functions
docs.text:
• ADF System Updates
  • A/A Interrogator
  • Autopilot
  • Command
  • Flight Data Readout
  • GPS
  • IFF Transponder
  • ILS
  • INS Data
  • LINK 16
  • Low Altitude Warning
  • Navigation FLIR
  • Ground Collision Warning System
  • Ground Speed
  • TACAN
  • TF Radar
  • UHF Radios

docs.title: Display Types
docs.text:
• Data (Data 1 and Data 2)
  • Menu (Menu 1 and Menu 2)
  • Submenu (various)

docs.title: DATA Key
docs.text:
• Data 1: Displays current flight data:

    • Bearing/range to selected steer point
    • ETE (Estimated Time Enroute)/ETA (Estimated Time of Arrival)
    • Altitude
    • Airspeed
    • Wind

  • Data 2: Provides future data:

    • TOA (Time Over Target/Area)
    • Fuel remaining at steer points beyond the currently selected point

docs.title: MENU Key
docs.text:
• Menu 1: Controls frequently used equipment:

    • TACAN
    • IFF
    • AAT (Air-to-Air Tactician)

  • Menu 2: Controls mission-specific items:

    • Update submenu
    • ILS

docs.title: Selection
docs.text:
1. Ensure the scratchpad is clear.
  2. Press the button next to the desired function or submenu.

docs.title: Data Entry
docs.text:
1. Type the new data into the scratchpad using the alphanumeric keys.
  2. Press the button next to the option you want to change.

docs.title: Special Function Keys
docs.text:
• GREC C/M: Selects/deselects UHF guard receiver and switches between preset channel or manual frequency.
  • MARK: Selects and stores present position (latitude/longitude).
  • A/P: Engages autopilot and displays the autopilot submenu.
  • I/P: Initiates IFF Identification of Position.
  • SHF: Shifts to uppercase alphanumerics.

  • CLR:

    • Clears scratchpad data.
    • First press: Removes the last alphanumeric entry.
    • Second press: Clears the entire entry.
    • Scratchpad Clear:
      • First press: Clears the top four display rows.
      • Second press: Clears the bottom two rows (useful for night operations to reduce canopy reflections).
    • Display Recall: Press MENU, DATA, or one of the top eight option buttons.

  • EMIS LMT:

    • Turns off all IFF modes.
    • Stops all RF transmissions except for the radar altimeter and TF (Terrain Following) radar (switches to LPI [Low Probability of Intercept] mode).

docs.title: UFC Tips
docs.text:
• Menu/Data Return: Pressing Menu 1 or Data 1 returns you to a starting point.
  • UHF Access: UHF frequency data is always displayed on rows 5 and 6. Access the UHF submenu from any display by pressing PB #5 or #6 (with a blank scratchpad).
  • Clear Scratchpad: Required for changing displays or selecting options (except for Data 1/2 or Menu 1/2).

docs.title: Dual Cockpit Control
docs.text:
• Simultaneous Access: Both cockpits can access UFC menus/submenus simultaneously.
  • Data Entry: Only the crew member who entered the data in the scratchpad can confirm it.
  • Input Priority: The last crew input, regardless of cockpit, is accepted.

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text:
• A/G: Air-to-ground
  • A/A: Air-to-air
  • AAT: Air-to-Air Tactician
  • ADI: Attitude Director Indicator
  • ADF: Automatic Direction Finder
  • AHRS: Attitude Heading Reference System

  • EHSI: Electronic Horizontal Situation Indicator
  • EMD: Engine Monitor Display
  • ETE: Estimated Time Enroute
  • ETA: Estimated Time of Arrival
  • EWWS: Electronic Warfare Warning Set
  • FLIR: Forward Looking Infrared
  • GPS: Global Positioning System
  • HOTAS: Hands On Throttle And Stick

  • IFF: Identification Friend or Foe
  • ILS: Instrument Landing System
  • ICS: Internal Countermeasures Set
  • INS: Inertial Navigation System
  • IPE: Increased Performance Engine
  • KTAS: Knots True Airspeed

  • LCD: Liquid Crystal Display
  • LPI: Low Probability of Intercept
  • MK-84: 2,000 lb general-purpose bomb
  • MTBF: Mean Time Between Failure
  • MPCD: Multipurpose Color Display
  • MPD: Multipurpose Display
  • nm: Nautical Mile
  • PPI: Plan Position Indicator
  • PP: Present Position
  • PVU: Precision Velocity Update
  • RF: Radio Frequency
  • RLG: Ring Laser Gyro
  • RWR: Radar Warning Receiver

docs.title: F-15E Front Cockpit Control Stick
docs.text: [Foldout 6: F-15E Front Cockpit Control Stick]

docs.title: T-O (Takeoff)
docs.text:
• Combined Mode (SEARCH, MRM):

    • Inboard:
      • EID/EWWS/NCTR display.
      • Scroll down.
      • Take command.
    • Outboard:
      • AAI (Air-to-Air Interrogator).
      • NAV data (for 3 seconds).

  • Quick Step/Master Mode Selection (FWD):

    • Down: Take command.
    • Forward: Master mode selection.

  • Weapon Release: Missile boresight.

  • Gunsight Stiffen/CMD (Countermeasure Dispenser) Manual:

    • Down: CMD Manual 4, look into turn enable.
    • Forward: Gunsight stiffen.

  • Manual AIM-9L/M SBR (Special Burst Ranging): Manual AIM-9L/M SBR.

  • AUTO ACQ (Automatic Acquisition):

    • Down: Elevation control.
    • Aft: Gun, vertical scan.

  • TWS (Track-While-Scan)/STT: TWS/STT.

  • LR BST (Long Range Boresight) (>1 second): CMD Manual 2.
  • Cage/Uncage (Down): Cage/Uncage.
  • GUN/SRM/MRM:
    • Aft: GUN/SRM/MRM.
    • Down: Cage/Uncage.

docs.title: T-DOV (Touchdown)
docs.text:
• Air-to-Ground Radar:

    • Inboard:
      • EID/EWWS/NCTR.
      • Snap look left (LEFT).
      • Snap look down (DOWN).
    • Outboard:
      • AAI.
      • NAV data (3 seconds).
      • Snap look right (RIGHT).

  • NAV FLIR (Navigation Forward Looking Infrared) with Coolie Down:

    • Up: Sequence point select.
    • Forward: Snap look down.
    • Aft: Snap look up.

  • Missile Boresight/Gunsight Stiffen:

    • Forward: Missile boresight.
    • Aft: Gunsight stiffen.

  • Look Into Turn Enable/Snap Look Enable:

    • Forward: Look into turn enable.
    • Aft: Snap look enable.

  • MAN (Manual) 2/CMD:

    • Up: MAN 2.
    • Down: CMD.

  • AUTO ACQ Switch/Undesignate:

    • Forward: Smaller window.
    • Aft: Larger window, undesignate.

  • Mode Reject/Cursor Control:

    • Forward: Mode reject.
    • Aft: Cursor control.

  • PSL (Priority Store List) Enable (with TGT [target] Cursor): Designate.

docs.title: T-DOV
docs.text:
• TSD (Tactical Situation Display):

    • Inboard:
      • EID/EWWS/NCTR.
      • Snap look down (DOWN).
    • Outboard:
      • AAI.
      • NAV data (3 seconds).

  • Sequence Point Select: Up: Sequence point select.

  • Missile Boresight/Gunsight Stiffen:

    • Forward: Missile boresight.
    • Aft: Gunsight stiffen.

  • Look Into Turn Enable: Forward: Look into turn enable.

  • CMD (Countermeasures Dispenser) Manual 1: Down: CMD Manual 1.
  • Track/Untrack: Down: Track/Untrack.

  • AUTO ACQ Switch:

    • Forward: Smaller cue footprint.
    • Aft: Larger cue footprint.

  • Return to P.P. (Present Position) Map: Forward: Return to P.P. Map.

  • Range/Bearing Line Control/Command Cue: Forward: Range/bearing line control/command cue.

docs.title: T-DOV
docs.text:
• TGT FLIR (Target Forward Looking Infrared):

    • Inboard:
      • EID/EWWS/NCTR.
      • Snap look left (LEFT).
      • Snap look down (DOWN).
    • Outboard:
      • AAI.
      • NAV data (3 seconds).
      • Snap look right (RIGHT).

  • NAV FLIR with Coolie Down:

    • Up: Sequence point select.
    • Forward: Snap look down.
    • Aft: Snap look up.

  • Missile Boresight/Gunsight Stiffen:

    • Forward: Missile boresight.
    • Aft: Gunsight stiffen.

  • Look Into Turn Enable/Snap Look Enable:

    • Forward: Look into turn enable.
    • Aft: Snap look enable, enable laser fire/stop fire.

  • CMD (Countermeasures Dispenser) Manual 1: Down: CMD Manual 1.

  • AUTO ACQ Switch:

    • Aft: Undesignate.
    • Forward (< 1 second): FOV change.

  • CMD/Track/Untrack:

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: This workbook (ACG-2) provides a detailed look at the F-15E propulsion system, covering its components, operation, and associated systems.

docs.title: Contents
docs.text:

  • Criterion Referenced Objectives (CROs)

  • End of Text Quiz
  • Glossary

docs.title: Criterion Referenced Objectives (CROs)
docs.text:
1. Identify the function and operational characteristics of the six major components of the F100-PW-220 engine.
  2. Identify the function and operational characteristics of the DEEC (Digital Electronic Engine Control) and the MFC (Main Fuel Control).
  3. Identify the function of engine controls and indicators.
  4. Identify the operating limits for the engine and engine-associated systems.
  5. Identify the function and operational characteristics of the variable ramps and the AICs (Air Inlet Controllers).
  6. Identify the basic operational characteristics of the engine oil system.
  7. Identify the operational characteristics of the engine secondary power system.
  8. Identify the operational characteristics of the fire warning/extinguishing system.
  9. Identify the indications and actions of a normal engine start.
  10. Given cockpit indications, identify engine-related malfunctions and the initial action required.
